summary: The document details the historical records concerning Antonio Cuesta del Valle, a Cuban exile and member of the anti-Castro group Comandos L, focusing on his capture by Cuban forces in 1966, imprisonment, and the subsequent efforts to secure his release. It highlights the involvement of his wife in negotiations, the interest of U.S. agencies such as the CIA, FBI, and Department of Justice, and references to operational activities and training camps in Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic linked to anti-Castro movements. This case underscores the complex dynamics of U.S.-Cuba relations during the Cold War.
key_findings: Antonio Cuesta del Valle was captured by Cuban forces in 1966 due to his involvement with the anti-Castro group Comandos L.
Efforts to ransom Cuesta del Valle involved negotiations with his wife and intermediaries, reflecting both humanitarian concerns and propaganda opportunities.
The document mentions operational activities and training camps in Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, associated with anti-Castro movements.

Cuesta del Valle's case attracted attention from several U.S. agencies, including the CIA, FBI, and Department of Justice, illustrating the broader context of Cold War tensions between the U.S. and Cuba.
